Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Implementation of Biodegradable Material Models in ANSYS

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1067750
Moore

Design optimization of many biodegradable medical implants is hampered by a lack of appropriate modeling tools. In these applications, the implant?s geometry and the mechanical loads to which it is subjected may be quite complex. This leads to spatially varying strain fields within the implant, which can cause certain parts to degrade faster than others. Unfortunately, the ability to model spatially dependent strain accelerated degradation is not well developed, and completely absent in the finite element modeling (FEM) tools commonly used in the medical device industry. FEM involves using computational techniques to solve for stresses in structures with complex geometries.

The Moore laboratory has begun constructing material description models for strain accelerated biodegradation processes. While initially successful in describing general characteristics, the further application of these models requires extensive model refinement. This GOALI proposal between Texas A&M University and ANSYS, Inc. aims to provide these next steps in model development. Specifically, the objectives are:
1. Evolve the initial biodegradable material models through an extensive set of measurements of the biodegradation behavior of several polymers subjected to physiologic cyclic loading.
2. Ensure the applicability of these models by deploying them in the ANSYS Mechanical Analysis FEM software package.
The availability of such modeling techniques will be of great benefit to medical implant designers who desire a predictable time to structural breakdown. There is significant value brought to the project by the participation of the industry partner, ANSYS, Inc. Their modeling software is being used by a large number of medical device manufacturers, all of whom are trying to develop biodegradable implants.

The development of these models will benefit communities other than medical device designers. Still within the biomedical community, there are many efforts to design functional tissue engineered constructs that can replace diseased body parts. In many cases, these constructs are made from biodegradable materials that are replaced by the actions of embedded or surrounding cells. The modeling techniques developed in this project will be applicable to these situations, with the addition of parameters that represent cell actions. Outside the biomedical community, there are many situations in which other sorts of materials experience strain accelerated degradation, including the built environment (man-made structures), automotive, and aerospace sectors. The commercial availability of these new models will benefit all of these fields, and educate a broader audience on the potential wide-ranging benefits of these new material models. The participation of the industry partner, ANSYS, Inc. adds significant value in making these models available to a broad community and publicizing their potential benefits. The post-doctoral and undergraduate researcher training aspects will benefit groups that are under-represented in engineering (females).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF GOALI project was aimed at providing a new class of material models in the framework of a commercially available computational modeling software. These material models describe the changes in mechanical properties of biodegradable materials that occur in response to the types of cyclic mechanical loads encountered in the body.  Current advancements in medicine include the continued development of minimally invasive surgical techniques, regenerative therapies and tissue engineering, and the use of biodegradable devices. Biodegradable devices allow physicians to deploy a device-based therapy that can perform a specific therapeutic function, e.g. healing a fracture, opening an artery, delivering a drug, etc. and then degrade away leaving the patient free of devices that are no longer necessary.

 In engineering practice, computational simulation allows low cost design and development work to be conducted in a virtual setting. In order to model the behavior of device designs, one must know how the materials respond to different conditions. This project was focused on the development of new theoretical and computational models that describe the behavior of biodegradable materials in response to mechanical loads. Models have now been developed that will enable device developers to evaluate designs computationally at relatively low cost prior to building actual prototypes. Computational models can now also be used in surgical planning, wherein doctors may test different configurations of a particular biodegradable device. Biodegradable polymers are often used as an encapsulating agent for time releases drug delivery. The mechanical environment influences the rate of degradation, which in turn affects the mechanical performance of the device. With the models developed as part of this project, biodegradable device–based drug delivery schemes can now be evaluated computationally and device performance optimized accordingly. In addition, this project inspired the development of a mew theoretical framework for modeling biologic tissue. This could be very important for tissue engineering applications as current models do not incorporate the complex mechanical behaviors exhibited by soft biologic tissues.

Several graduate students received valuable training and experience in working on this project, including two from under-represented groups in the sciences. In addition to the training and professional development, each received co-authorship on one or more publications in peer-reviewed scientific journals. They were also given opportunities to present their work at major conferences in the field. This will be invaluable as they launch their respective careers as independent scientists. In addition, several undergraduate research assistants (including three from under-represented groups) also received valuable experience and opportunities to publish and present their work. Additionally, a summer outreach research program was developed wherein local high school students from under-represented groups were given an opportunity to learn about the research project, and gain experience in an engineering research laboratory with the goal of sparking their interest in engineering and attending college.

Finally, the PI on this project is Desert Storm era military veteran and member of an under-represented group in STEM. In addition to providing a solid foundation on which to build his career, this project inspired the development of a novel theoretical framework for the mechanical characterization of biologic tissues that has essentially become a new line of research that is ongoing.
